summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys to Judge Alison J. Nathan requesting the court order the Bureau of Prisons to grant Maxwell weekend and holiday access to a government-provided laptop for reviewing discovery. The letter argues the restriction impedes her trial preparation and notes the government has no objection.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The client of the law firm, currently incarcerated and seeking expanded access to a laptop to review discovery for her defense.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case to whom the request for an order is addressed.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP who signed the letter on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell.

connections.description: Everdell is writing and making a legal request to the court on behalf of his client, Ghislaine Maxwell.
Maxwell is the defendant in a criminal case over which Judge Nathan is presiding.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team is requesting court-ordered weekend and holiday access to a government-provided laptop for discovery review, citing the voluminous nature of the evidence.
The government has no objection to Maxwell having seven-day-a-week access to the laptop, but MDC officials have not lifted the restriction despite requests.
Maxwell previously had daily laptop access, including weekends, during a 14-day COVID-19 quarantine in November-December 2020.
The defense argues the prison computer is inadequate for reviewing large portions of the recently produced discovery, causing her to lose review time.
The trial is scheduled for July 12, 2021, and Maxwell must review millions of documents to prepare her defense.
